page.title: 14AIR TRAFFIC CONTROL
page.content: Aircraft approaching London Heathrow Airport from the North of England or the Midlands pass right over Bovingdon. The airway called 'Amber 1' is an aerial 'corridor' along which commercial aircraft fly. This is an area of controlled airspace where every aircraft has to be in touch with the nearest Air Traffic Control Centre. Bovingdon is a reporting beacon and holding point for the 'London Terminal Control Area'. If Heathrow Airport is very busy, planes may have to wait their turn to land. They do this in a 'stack' by flying in an elliptical path around a reporting beacon like Bovingdon. Each layer of the stack is 1000 feet apart. As the lowest planes get their turn to go and land the others waiting go down one layer to await their turn.
